Kittens are just going to be a handful.
If he is clawing at curtains put them up where he can't get them.
Make sure he has at least ONE good scratching post. A lot of the ones you can buy at the pet store are kind of shitty because they're not tall enough or don't have a wide enough base. If the cat doesn't feel like it can put its weight into the scratching post it wont feel comfortable using it.
I'd also suggest spending money on a cat tree, or making one if you have some basic tools and aren't retarded.
Its a good scratching post, it also gives the cat something they can get up high on that they won't get yelled at for.
I'd also suggest, especially while they're young, to get them worked enough that they start breathing heavy. The kitten gets some play and exercise, and you just tuckered him out enough that he's going to eat and then pass out for a few hours.

Don't use clay based litter.
Have an anti-tracking mat around the box anyways.
Always use a hooded litterbox. You can run a vent hose to an always-on low speed/high CFM fan going out a window or hole in the wall. Don't put the fan in/on the box if you can help it. Maybe skip the fan if window venting (screen the exit) works well enough for you.
Change ALL the litter at least weekly and scoop the box immediately. Wash and disinfect the box when you do.
NO CATS ON TABLES AND COUNTERS. ENFORCE STRICTLY.
Outdoor cats that leave the backyard are extremely likely to die.
Cats that spend unsupervised time outdoors at all are likely to contract parasites and illnesses from eating wild animals and interacting with ferals.
Remember cats are prey as well as predators. It's basically a pointy rabbit.

Enjoy your cat.

- YES, paleontologists have been fooled by it before (Qi et al. 2014)

Once upon a time in a far-off land, there was a brave and noble dog named Casper. Casper was the guardian of a flock of sheep that roamed the rolling hills and green pastures of the countryside.

One day, as Casper was patrolling the perimeter of the sheep's grazing grounds, he heard a faint yipping in the distance. As the sound grew louder, Casper knew that it was a pack of coyotes, fierce and cunning predators that would stop at nothing to snatch a meal from the sheep.

Without hesitation, Casper charged towards the coyotes, barking and growling fiercely. The coyotes, startled by Casper's boldness, hesitated for a moment before launching their attack.

Casper fought bravely, his sharp teeth and powerful jaws tearing into the coyotes' fur and flesh. The battle raged on, with the coyotes snarling and snapping at Casper, and Casper baring his teeth and lashing out with his paws.

Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, the last of the coyotes lay dying at Casper's feet. Casper had triumphed, and the sheep were safe.

Word of Casper's bravery and valor quickly spread throughout the land, and the sheepherders praised him as a hero. Casper was hailed as a champion, and his name became known throughout the kingdom as the greatest guardian of sheep that had ever lived.

Casper lived out the rest of his days in peace, watching over the flock and defending them from any threat that dared to cross his path. And though he was no longer a young dog, his spirit and courage never wavered, for he knew that he had been chosen to protect the sheep, and he would do so until his last breath.

Thus ends the epic tale of Casper the heroic dog, who single-handedly defeated eight coyotes to defend his beloved sheep flock. Though he may have been just a humble dog, he will forever be remembered as a true hero, and his legacy will live on in the hearts of all who knew him.

com: why is it that mutt dogs are generally more healthier than purebreds? am i missing something here?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4371084
I've noticed this too and I think it's because shelter mutts are just as likely to have bad breeding as the stereotypical inbred show dog. Lots of backyard breeding experiments gone awry end up in shelter kennels and since these breeders don't do any kind of health screening, you get sickly dogs with fucked up proportions there too.

Real hybrid vigor is present in dog populations with lots of genetic diversity going back generations and with a minimum of human selection for any specific task or proportions. Desi dogs and carolina dogs are good examples, as well as some of the ancient breeds like malamutes and spitzes. These dogs are statistically healthier and live longer.

That is an excellent question for multiple reasons:

1. It will be a fun project to reconstruct the vocal cords of this animal, there was even a YouTube video speculating on how T.Rex most likely sounded like a double bass, due to modern birds (of the large variety) using closed mouth vocals to communicate over a large distance, similar to elephants.

2. But on a more opinionated note. I find it disappointing that there was no grand designs towards this animal, and it reminds me of the enthusiastically, cheesy early iguanodon interpretations. It's better to imagine the creature as a 19th century Godzilla while being based on a single jawbone, rather than a lackluster paragraph on Wikipedia. Imagination is important to tell stories and to fill in the intellectual gaps, (as long as there is systematic evidence).

Crete is an underrated paleo landscape were big was small and vise versa, and it's eerie to think that the ancient Greeks noted the lack of hostile fauna of the island, and they all seemed to have disappeared like the Minoans.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>4370313
I recently had to euthanize my (18 year old, born July 2004) cat because of end stage kidney failure. She was 100% fine and acting normal until the day she had a seizure. Then she was beyond saving within another day and a half. She didn't even have the weight loss/lack of appetite that is common with the disease.
This can be kidney disease or hyperthyroidism (sometimes both, they often go hand in hand). If their kidneys aren't working well they feel nauseous from toxins building up in their system and avoid eating and sometimes vomit after eating. Would you say your cat still has a healthy appetite? How are you giving them water? Litter box habits remain unchanged? Usually amount of energy/still has the motivation to do what it enjoys?
Water fountains encourage them to drink water a lot more. For food try giving canned food only (good quality brand, if kidney issues are suspected low protein specific kidney diet is best). If you must feed kibble try adding warm water to soften them and see if it encourages your cat to eat more. In the case of hard, dry kibble dental pain could also be a factor. You won't know unless you bring them in.
